Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Metal Nanoclusters as Effective Electrocatalysts for Oxygen Reduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry supports the research efforts of Professor Shaowei Chen at the University of California - Santa Cruz to investigate the electrocatalytic activity of non-platinum metal nanoclusters for oxygen reduction, a reaction that is important to fuel cell technology. The proposed research is built upon preliminary studies demonstrating that (i) (sub)nanometer-sized gold clusters exhibit much enhanced electrocatalytic activity and (ii) gold nanocatalysts on oxide supports may facilitate oxygen adsorption and eventual reduction. The project focuses on the following two aspects: (i) preparation and characterization of functional nanocomposites based on Au/Cu nanoclusters and oxide nanostructures, and (ii) interfacial engineering of nanocatalysts for the preparation of surface alloy nanoparticles. Ultimately, an unambiguous correlation between the nanocomposite structures and electrocatalytic activity will be established, which will help to improve electrocatalytic performance. Professor Chen and coworkers will also be actively involved in various outreach activities targeting minority, women, and disadvantaged undergraduate students (e.g., the UC LEADS, ACCESS, and SURF programs) and qualified high-school students (e.g., COSMOS, and Summer Internship Program).

To render fuel cell technology commercially viable, it is imperative to develop effective catalysts for both the anodic and cathodic reactions so as to achieve the current density that is needed for practical applications. Whereas platinum-based nanoparticles have been traditionally used as the catalysts of choice, the efforts have been hampered by the high costs and limited reserves of platinum. Therefore, this project focuses on catalysts based on more abundant and/or less expensive non-platinum metals such as gold and copper, and may lead to a new class of platinum-free catalysts for fuel cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fuel cell technologies have long been attracting extensive interest as a portable and renewable energy source. However, this technology is currently limited in commercial setting due to the high costs and relatively low efficiency of fuel cell catalysts, largely as a result of the sluggish kinetics of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the fuel cell cathode,  O2 + 4H+ + 4e → 2H2O. Thus, development of effective catalysts for the ORR is a critical first step in the large-scale commercialization of fuel cell technology, which are largely based on precious metals such as Pt, Pd, and Au. Extensive research has found that the ORR activity varies with the metal d band center relative to the Fermi level, and the variation exhibits a volcano shaped trend that was predicted by Sabatier years ago. Pt is the most active metal but there is still room for improvement. To reach the peak of this theoretical volcano, a number of strategies have been adopted. These include the formation of core/shell and homogeneous alloy nanoparticles, size manipulation, controlled growth of particle shape or facet orientation, and organic functionalization.  This is the fundamental basis of the research project, where we demonstrated that metal/ligand (substrate) interactions might be exploited as a new, effective parameter in manipulating the electron density of the metal nanoparticles and hence the bonding interactions with oxygen intermediates. Indeed, within the award period, we prepared a series of metal nanoparticles (e.g., Pt, Pd, AuPd, AuAg, etc) that were capped with diverse organic ligands (e.g., acetylene and olefin derivatives) forming different metal-carbon covalent bonds, and careful electrochemical studies showed that the nanoparticles exhibited markedly higher ORR activity than the mercapto-capped counterparts. This was largely accounted for by the reduced metal-ligand interfacial linkages, which facilitated spilling of core electrons into the organic capping layers. The diminished electron density of the metal cores led to weakened bonding interactions with oxygen species and hence enhanced ORR activity.

Similar enhancement was achieved by depositing metal nanoparticles on graphene nanosheets. As electron transfer was facilitated from the supported metal nanoparticles to the structural defects of the graphene, we found that the ORR activity might be enhanced and optimized within the context of the chemical identity and concentration of graphene structural defects which might be readily controlled by simple hydrothermal treatment. Significantly, for metal/graphene nanocomposites, we found that the optimal defect concentrations of the graphene substrates increased in the order of Pt < Pd < Cu, in good agreement with the volcano plot where the oxygen binding energy increased in the same order.

In the research project, we also explored the applications of mesoporous carbons deliberately doped with selected heteroatoms as effective, metal-free ORR catalysts. The formation of mesopores (2 – 50 nm) is critical in facilitating the mass transport of reaction species, and doping is necessary to activate the originally inert carbon matrix for ORR. For instance, we developed an effective approach based on thermally removable FeOOH nanorods as the structural templates to the preparation of varied N-doped mesorporous carbons and observed ORR activities that were highly comparable to that of commercial Pt/C catalysts. We even used the N-doped mesoporous carbons as the cathode to construct a Zn-air battery and the performance was found to better than that with commercial Pt/C catalysts.
